8.verse: “‘If you prepare a young bull as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] or sacrifice, whether it is for a ·special promise [vow] or a ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offering [Lev. 3:1] to the LORD,

9.verse: bring a ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] with the bull. It should be ·six quarts [three-tenths of an ephah] of ·fine [choice] flour mixed with ·two quarts [half a hin] of olive oil.

10.verse: Also bring ·two quarts [half a hin] of wine as a drink offering. This offering is made by fire, and its smell will be pleasing to the LORD.

11.verse: Prepare each bull or ·male sheep [ram], lamb or young goat this way.

12.verse: Do this for every one of the animals you bring.

13.verse: “‘All ·citizens [natives] must do these things in this way, and the smell of their offerings by fire will be pleasing to the LORD.

14.verse: ·From now on [Throughout your generations] if ·foreigners [resident aliens] who live among you want to make offerings by fire so the smell will be pleasing to the LORD, they must offer them the same way you do.

15.verse: As for the ·people [community; congregation; assembly], the ·law [statute; ordinance; requirement] is the same for you and for ·foreigners [resident aliens], and it will be ·from now on [a perpetual requirement]; you and the ·foreigners [resident aliens] are alike before the LORD.

16.verse: The ·teachings [instructions; laws] and ·rules [regulations] are the same for you and for the ·foreigners [resident aliens] among you.’”

17.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

18.verse: “Tell the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel]: ‘You are going to another land, where I am taking you.

19.verse: When you eat the food there, ·offer [elevate] part of it to the LORD.

20.verse: ·Offer [Elevate] a loaf of bread from the first of your ·grain [or dough], which will be your ·offering [elevation offering] from the threshing floor.

21.verse: ·From now on [Throughout your generations] ·offer [elevate] to the LORD the first part of your ·grain [or dough].

22.verse: “‘Now what if you ·forget [unintentionally fail] to ·obey [do] any of these commands the LORD gave Moses?

23.verse: These are the LORD’s commands given to you through Moses, which began the day the LORD ·gave them to [commanded] you and will continue ·from now on [throughout your generations].

24.verse: If the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] ·forget [unintentionally fail] to ·obey [do] one of these commands, all the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] must offer a young bull as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17], a smell pleasing to the LORD. By law you must also give the ·grain [gift; tribute] offering [Lev. 2:1] and the drink offering with it, and you must bring a male goat as a ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering.

25.verse: “‘The priest will ·remove that sin for all the Israelites so they will belong to the LORD [atone for all the community/congregation/assembly of the sons/children of Israel]. They are forgiven, because they ·didn’t know they were sinning [sinned unintentionally]. For the unintentional wrong they did they brought offerings to the LORD, an offering by fire and a ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering.

26.verse: So all of the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] of ·Israel [the sons/children of Israel] and the ·foreigners [resident aliens] living among them will be forgiven. ·No one meant to do wrong [They were all involved in unintentional sin].

27.verse: “‘If just one person sins ·without meaning to [unintentionally], a year-old female goat must be brought for a ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering.

28.verse: The priest will ·remove [atone for] the sin of the person who sinned ·accidentally [unintentionally]. He will ·remove it before the LORD [atone for him]; and the person will be forgiven.

29.verse: The same ·teaching [instruction; law] is for everyone who sins ·accidentally [unintentionally]—for those ·born Israelites [natives] and for ·foreigners [resident aliens] living among you.

30.verse: “‘But anyone who sins ·on purpose [with a high hand; knowingly] ·is against [insults] the LORD and must be cut off from the people, whether it is ·someone born among you [a native] or a ·foreigner [resident alien].

31.verse: That person has ·turned against [despised] the LORD’s word and has ·not obeyed [broken] his commands. Such a person must surely be cut off from the others. He is guilty.’”

32.verse: A Man Worked on the Sabbath - When the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] were still in the ·desert [wilderness], they found a man gathering wood on the Sabbath day [Gen. 2:2–3; Ex. 20:8–11; 35:2; Deut. 5:13–15].

33.verse: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and all the people.

34.verse: They held the man under guard, because they did not know what to do with him.

35.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses, “The man must surely die. All the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] must kill him by ·throwing stones at [stoning] him outside the camp.”

36.verse: So all the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, as the LORD commanded Moses.

37.verse: The Tassels - The LORD said to Moses,

38.verse: “Speak to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] and tell them this: ‘·Tie several pieces of thread together and attach them to [Make fringes/tassels on] the corners of your clothes. Put a blue thread ·in each one of these tassels [on the fringe/tassel of each corner]. Wear them ·from now on [throughout your generations].

39.verse: You will have these ·tassels [fringes] to look at to remind you of all the LORD’s commands. Then you will obey them and not ·be disloyal by following what your bodies and eyes want [follow after your own heart or your own eyes to be unfaithful/play the harlot after them].

40.verse: Then you will remember to obey all my commands, and you will be God’s holy people.

41.verse: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of Egypt to be your God [Ex. 12–15]. I am the LORD your God.’”

1.verse: Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and On - Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and On turned against Moses. (Korah was the son of Izhar [26:9–11; 27:3; Ex. 6:21, 24], the son of Kohath, the son of Levi; Dathan and Abiram were brothers [Deut. 11:6; Ps. 106:17], the sons of Eliab; and On was the son of Peleth; Dathan, Abiram, and On were from the tribe of Reuben [Gen. 49:3–4].)

2.verse: These men gathered two hundred fifty other ·Israelite men [men of the sons/children of Israel], ·well-known leaders [men of name/reputation] chosen by the ·community [congregation; assembly], and ·challenged [confronted] Moses.

3.verse: They ·came as a group to speak to [assembled against] Moses and Aaron and said, “You have gone too far. All the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] are holy, every one of them, and the LORD is among them [Ex. 19:6]. So why do you put yourselves above all the ·people [assembly; crowd] of the LORD?”

4.verse: When Moses heard this, he ·bowed facedown [fell on his face].

5.verse: Then he said to Korah and all his ·followers [community; congregation; assembly]: “Tomorrow morning the LORD will show who belongs to him. He will bring the one who is holy near to him; he will bring to himself the person he chooses.

6.verse: So Korah, you and all your ·followers [community; congregation; assembly] do this: Get some ·pans for burning incense [censers; firepans].

7.verse: Tomorrow put fire and incense in them and take them before the LORD [Lev. 10:1–2]. He will choose the man who is holy. You ·Levites [sons/descendants of Levi] have gone too far.”

8.verse: Moses also said to Korah, “Listen, you ·Levites [sons of Levi].

9.verse: The God of Israel has ·separated [divided] you from the rest of the ·Israelites [community/congregation/assembly of Israel]. He brought you near to himself to do the work in the LORD’s ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle] and to stand before all the ·Israelites [community; congregation; assembly] and ·serve [minister to] them [8:14; Ex. 32:29; Lev. 8–9; Deut. 33:8–11]. ·Isn’t that enough [Is it too little for you]?

10.verse: He has brought you and all your ·fellow [brother] ·Levites [sons of Levi] near to himself, yet now you ·want to be priests [seek the priesthood].

11.verse: You and your ·followers [community; congregation; assembly] have joined together against the LORD. ·Your complaint is not against Aaron [Who is Aaron that you complain/grumble against him?].”

12.verse: Then Moses called Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, but they said, “We will not come!

13.verse: Is it too little that you have brought us out of a ·fertile land [land flowing with milk and honey; Egypt] to this ·desert [wilderness] to kill us? Now you want to ·order us around [lord it over us].

14.verse: You haven’t brought us into a ·fertile land [land flowing with milk and honey; Ex. 3:8]; you haven’t given us ·any land [an inheritance] with fields and vineyards. Will you put out the eyes of these men? No! We will not come!”

15.verse: Then Moses became very angry and said to the LORD, “Don’t accept their ·gifts [tribute]. I have not taken anything from them, not even a donkey, and I have not done wrong to any of them.”

16.verse: Then Moses said to Korah, “You and all your ·followers [community; congregation; assembly] must stand before the LORD tomorrow. And Aaron will stand there with you and them.

17.verse: Each of you must take your ·pan [censer; firepan] and put incense in it; present these two hundred fifty ·pans [censers; firepans] before the LORD. You and Aaron must also present your ·pans [censers; firepans].”

18.verse: So each man got his ·pan [censer; firepan] and put burning incense in it and stood with Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the Meeting Tent.

19.verse: Korah ·gathered [assembled] all his ·followers [community; congregation; assembly] who were against Moses and Aaron, and they stood at the entrance to the Meeting Tent. Then the glory of the LORD [representing God’s manifest presence, often in the form of fire and smoke] appeared to everyone.

20.verse: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

21.verse: “·Move away [Separate/Divide yourselves] from these men so I can destroy them quickly.”

22.verse: But Moses and Aaron ·bowed facedown [fell on their faces] and cried out, “God, you are the God ·over [of] the spirits of all ·people [flesh; 27:16; Gen 2:7]. Please don’t be angry with this whole ·group [community; congregation; assembly]. Only one man has really sinned.”

23.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses,

24.verse: “Tell ·everyone [the community/congregation/assembly] to ·move away from [go up from around] the ·tents [dwellings] of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”

25.verse: Moses stood and went to Dathan and Abiram; the elders of Israel followed him.

26.verse: Moses warned the people, “·Move away [Turn aside] from the tents of these evil men! Don’t touch anything of theirs, or you will be ·destroyed [swept away] because of their sins.”

27.verse: So they ·moved away [went up] from the ·tents [dwellings] of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram were standing outside their tents with their wives, children, and little babies.

28.verse: Then Moses said, “Now you will know that the LORD has sent me to do all these things; it was not ·my idea [from my heart/mind].

29.verse: If these men die a normal death—·the way men usually die [if a normal fate comes on them]—then the LORD did not really send me.

30.verse: But if the LORD ·does [creates] something new, you will know they have ·insulted [despised] the LORD. The ground will open and swallow them. They will be buried alive and will go to ·the place of the dead [Sheol; the grave or the underworld], and everything that belongs to them will go with them.”

31.verse: When Moses finished saying these things, the ground under the men split open.

32.verse: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them and all their families. All Korah’s men and everything they owned went down.

33.verse: They were buried alive, going to ·the place of the dead [Sheol ;the grave or the underworld], and everything they owned went with them. Then the earth covered them. They ·died and were gone [perished] from the ·community [assembly; crowd].

34.verse: ·The people of [All] Israel around them heard their screams and ran away, saying, “The earth will swallow us, too!”

35.verse: Then a fire came ·down [or out] from the LORD and ·destroyed [consumed] the two hundred fifty men who had presented the incense [Lev. 10:1–2].

37.verse: “Tell Eleazar son of Aaron, the priest, to take all the ·incense pans [censers; firepans] out of the ·fire [flames]. Have him scatter the ·coals [fire] a long distance away. But the ·incense pans [censers; firepans] are still holy.

38.verse: Take the ·pans [censers; firepans] of these men who sinned and lost their lives, and hammer them into flat sheets that will be used to cover the altar. They are holy, because they were presented to the LORD, and they will be a sign to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel].”

39.verse: So Eleazar the priest gathered all the bronze ·pans [censers; firepans] that had been brought by the men who were burned up. He had the ·pans [censers; firepans] hammered into flat sheets to put on the altar,

40.verse: as the LORD had commanded him through Moses. These sheets were to remind the Israelites that only ·descendants [the seed] of Aaron should burn incense before the LORD. Anyone else would die like Korah and his ·followers [community; congregation; assembly].

41.verse: Aaron Saves the People - The next day all the ·Israelites [community/congregation/assembly of the sons/children of Israel] ·complained [grumbled] against Moses and Aaron and said, “You have killed the LORD’s people.”

42.verse: When the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] ·gathered [assembled] to ·complain [grumble] against Moses and Aaron, they turned toward the Meeting Tent, and the cloud covered it. The glory of the LORD [representing his manifest presence] appeared.

43.verse: Then Moses and Aaron went in front of the Meeting Tent.

45.verse: “Move away from ·these people [this community/congregation/assembly] so I can ·destroy [consume] them quickly.” So Moses and Aaron ·bowed facedown [fell on their faces].

46.verse: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Get your ·pan [censer; firepan], and put fire from the altar and incense in it. Hurry to the people and ·remove their sin [make atonement for them]. The LORD is angry with them; the ·sickness [plague; pestilence] has already started.”

47.verse: So Aaron did as Moses said. He ran to the middle of the ·people [assembly; crowd], where the ·sickness [plague; pestilence] had already started among them. So Aaron offered the incense to ·remove their sin [make atonement for them].

48.verse: He stood between the dead and the living, and the ·sickness [plague; pestilence] stopped there.

49.verse: But 14,700 people died from that ·sickness [plague; pestilence], in addition to those who died because of Korah.

50.verse: Then Aaron went back to Moses at the entrance to the Meeting Tent. The terrible ·sickness [plague; pestilence] had been stopped.

1.verse: Aaron’s Walking Stick Buds - The LORD said to Moses,

2.verse: “Speak to the ·people [sons; children] of Israel and get twelve ·walking sticks [staffs] from them—one from the leader of each ·tribe [family group; house of their fathers]. Write the name of each man on his ·stick [staff], and

3.verse: on the ·stick [staff] from Levi, write Aaron’s name. There must be one ·stick [staff] for the head of each ·tribe [family; house of their fathers].

4.verse: Put them in the Meeting Tent in front of the ·Ark of the Agreement [Treaty; Covenant; Testimony; Ex. 25:10], where I meet with you.

5.verse: I will choose one man whose ·walking stick [staff] will begin to grow leaves [indicating God’s affirmation]; in this way I will stop the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] from always ·complaining [grumbling] against you.”

6.verse: So Moses spoke to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel]. Each of the twelve leaders gave him a ·walking stick [staff]—one from each ·tribe [family; house of their fathers]—and Aaron’s ·walking stick [staff] was among them.

7.verse: Moses put them before the LORD in the Tent of the ·Agreement [Testimony; Treaty; Covenant].

8.verse: The next day, when Moses entered the Tent of the ·Agreement [Testimony; Treaty; Covenant], he saw that Aaron’s ·stick [staff] (which stood for the family of Levi) had grown leaves. It had even budded, blossomed, and produced almonds.

9.verse: So Moses brought out to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] all the ·walking sticks [staffs] from the LORD’s presence. They all looked, and each man took back his ·stick [staff].

10.verse: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Put Aaron’s ·walking stick [staff] back in front of the ·Ark of the Agreement [Treaty; Covenant; Testimony; Ex. 25:10]. It will ·remind [serve as a sign to] these people who are always turning against me to stop their ·complaining [grumbling] against me so they won’t die.”

11.verse: So Moses obeyed what the LORD commanded him.

12.verse: The ·people [sons/children] of Israel said to Moses, “We ·are going to die [will perish]! We are ·destroyed [lost]. We are all ·destroyed [lost]!

13.verse: Anyone who even comes near the Holy Tent of the LORD will die. Will we all ·die [perish]?”

1.verse: The Work of the Priests and Levites - The LORD said to Aaron, “You, your sons, and your ·family [father’s house] are now responsible for any wrongs done against the Holy Place; you and your sons are responsible for any wrongs done against the priests.

2.verse: Bring with you your ·fellow [brother] Levites from your tribe, and they will ·help [join; the name Levi means “joined”] you and your sons serve in the Tent of the ·Agreement [Testimony; Treaty; Covenant; Ex. 25:10].

3.verse: They are under your control, to do all the work that needs to be done in the Tent. But they must not go near the things in the Holy Place or near the altar. If they do, both you and they will die.

4.verse: They will join you in taking care of the Meeting Tent. They must do the work at the Tent, and no ·one else [stranger; outsider] may come near you.

5.verse: “You must take care of the Holy Place and the altar so that I won’t become angry with the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] again.

6.verse: I myself chose your ·fellow [brother] Levites from among the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] as a gift given for you to the LORD, to work at the Meeting Tent.

7.verse: But only you and your sons may ·serve as priests [guard the priesthood]. Only you may serve at the altar or go behind the curtain. I am giving you this gift of serving as a priest, and ·anyone else [any stranger/outsider] who comes near the Holy Place will be put to death.”

8.verse: Then the LORD said to Aaron, “I myself make you responsible for the offerings given to me. All the holy offerings that the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] give to me, I give to you and your sons as your share, your ·continual [perpetual] portion.

9.verse: Your share of the ·holy offerings [holy of the holy things] is that part which is not burned. When the people bring me gifts as ·most holy offerings [holy of the holy things], whether they are ·grain [gift; tribute; Lev. 2:1] or ·sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] or ·penalty [guilt; reparation; Lev. 5:14—6:7] offerings, they will be set apart for you and your sons.

10.verse: You must eat the offering in ·a most holy place [the holy of holy places]. Any male may eat it, but you must respect it as holy.

11.verse: “I also give you the offerings the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] present to me. I give these to you and your sons and daughters as your ·continual [perpetual] share. Anyone in your ·family [house] who is clean [in a ritual sense] may eat it.

12.verse: “And I give you all the best olive oil and all the best new wine and grain. This is what ·the Israelites [they] give to me, the LORD, from the first crops they harvest.

13.verse: When they bring to the LORD all the first things they harvest, they will be yours. Anyone in your ·family [house] who is clean [in a ritual sense] may eat these things.

14.verse: “Everything in Israel that is ·given to the LORD [devoted; set aside for God] is yours.

15.verse: The ·first one born [one that opens the womb] to any family, whether people or animals, will be offered to the LORD. And that will be yours. But you must ·make a payment for [ransom; redeem] every firstborn child and every firstborn animal that is unclean [in a ritual sense].

16.verse: When they are one month old, you ·must make a payment for [ransom; redeem] them of ·two ounces [five shekels, that is twenty gerahs] of silver, as set by the Holy Place measure [3:40–50; Ex. 13:2, 11–16].

17.verse: “But you must not ·make a payment for [ransom; redeem] the firstborn ox or sheep or goat. Those animals are holy. ·Sprinkle [Dash] their blood on the altar and ·burn [turn into smoke] their fat as an offering made by fire. The smell is pleasing to the LORD.

18.verse: But the meat will be yours, just as the breast that is presented and the right thigh will be yours.

19.verse: Anything the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] present as holy gifts I, the LORD, give to you, your sons and daughters as your ·continual [perpetual] portion. This is a lasting ·agreement [treaty; covenant] of salt [representing perpetual agreement because salt can survive fire; Lev. 2:13] before the LORD for you and your children forever.”

20.verse: The LORD also said to Aaron, “You will not inherit any of the land, and you will not own any land among the other people [Gen. 49:5–7]. I will be yours. Out of all the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], only you will inherit me.

21.verse: “When the people of Israel give me a ·tenth [tithe] of what they make, I will give that tenth to the ·Levites [sons of Levi; Lev. 27:30–32; Deut. 12:17–19; 14:22–29]. This is their payment for the work they do serving at the Meeting Tent.

22.verse: But the other ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] must never go near the Meeting Tent, or they will die for their sin.

23.verse: Only the Levites should work in the Meeting Tent and be responsible for any sins against it. This is a ·rule from now on [perpetual statute/ordinance/requirement throughout your generations]. The Levites will not inherit any land among the other ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel],

24.verse: but when the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] give a ·tenth [tithe] of everything they make to me, I will give that ·tenth [tithe] to the Levites as a reward. That is why I said about the Levites: ‘They will not inherit any land among the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel].’”

25.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

26.verse: “Speak to the Levites and tell them: ‘You will receive a ·tenth [tithe] of everything the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] make, which I will give to you. But you must give a ·tenth of that [tenth of a tenth; tithe of a tithe] back to the LORD.

27.verse: I will accept your offering just as much as I accept the offerings from others, who give ·new grain [the grain of the threshing floor] or ·new wine [the fullness of the winepress].

28.verse: In this way you will present an offering to the LORD as the other ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] do. When you receive a ·tenth [tithe] from the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], you will give a ·tenth [tithe] of that to Aaron, the priest, as the LORD’s share.

29.verse: Choose the best and holiest part from what you are given as the portion you must give to the LORD.’

30.verse: “Say to the Levites: ‘When you present the best, it will be accepted as much as the ·grain [product of the threshing floor] and ·wine [product of the wine press] from the other people.

31.verse: You and your ·families [house] may eat all that is left anywhere, because it is your pay for your work in the Meeting Tent.

32.verse: And if you always give the best part to the LORD, you will never be guilty. If you do not ·sin against [profane] the holy offerings of the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], you will not die.’”

1.verse: The Offering for Cleansing - The LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

2.verse: “These are the ·teachings [statutes; ordinances; requirements] that the LORD commanded. Tell the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] to get a young red ·cow [heifer] that does not have ·anything wrong with it [a defect and is without a blemish] and that has never ·been worked [worn a yoke].

3.verse: Give the ·cow [heifer] to Eleazar the priest; he will take it outside the camp and ·kill [slaughter] it in his presence.

4.verse: Then Eleazar the priest must put some of its blood on his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the Meeting Tent.

5.verse: The whole ·cow [heifer] must be burned while he watches; the skin, the meat, the blood, and ·the intestines [its dung] must all be burned.

6.verse: Then the priest must take a cedar stick, a hyssop branch, and a red string [the redness of the heifer and these objects probably represent blood] and throw them onto the burning ·cow [heifer].

7.verse: After the priest has washed himself and his clothes with water, he may come back into the camp, but he will be unclean [in a ritual sense] until evening.

8.verse: The man who burns the ·cow [heifer] must wash himself and his clothes in water; he will be unclean until evening.

9.verse: “Then someone who is clean [in a ritual sense] will collect the ashes from the ·cow [heifer] and put them in a clean place outside the camp. The ·Israelites [community/congregation/assembly of the sons/children of Israel] will keep these ashes to use in the cleansing water, in a ·special ceremony to cleanse away sin [sin offering; or purification offering; Lev. 4:3].

10.verse: The man who collected the ·cow’s [heifer’s] ashes must wash his clothes and be unclean until evening. This is a lasting ·rule [statute; ordinance; requirement] ·for the Israelites [in their midst] and for the ·foreigners [resident aliens] among them.

11.verse: “Those who touch a dead person’s body will be unclean [in a ritual sense] for seven days.

12.verse: They must ·wash themselves with the cleansing [purify themselves with the] water on the third day and on the seventh day; then they will be clean. But if they do not ·wash themselves [purify themselves] on the third day and the seventh day, they cannot be clean.

13.verse: If those who touch a dead person’s body ·stay unclean [do not purify themselves] and go to the LORD’s ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle], it becomes unclean; they must be cut off from Israel. If the cleansing water is not sprinkled on them, they are unclean and will stay unclean.

14.verse: “This is the ·teaching [instruction; law] about someone who dies in a tent: Anyone in the tent or anyone who enters it will be unclean [in a ritual sense] for seven days.

15.verse: And every open jar or pot without a cover becomes unclean.

16.verse: If anyone is ·outside [in the open field] and touches someone who was killed by a sword or who died [a natural death], or if anyone touches a human bone or a grave, that person will be unclean for seven days.

17.verse: “So you must use the ashes from the burnt sin [or purification; Lev. 4:3] offering to make that person clean [in a ritual sense] again. Pour ·fresh [running; living] water over the ashes into a jar.

18.verse: A clean person must take a hyssop branch and dip it into the water, and then he must sprinkle it over the tent and all its objects. He must also sprinkle the people who were there, as well as anyone who touched a bone, or the body of someone who was killed, or a dead person, or a grave.

19.verse: The person who is clean must sprinkle this water on the unclean people on the third day and on the seventh day. On the seventh day they will ·become clean [be purified]. They must wash their clothes and take a bath, and they will be clean that evening.

20.verse: If any who are unclean do not become ·clean [purified], they must be cut off from the ·community [assembly; crowd]. Since they were not sprinkled with the cleansing water, they stay unclean, and they could make the LORD’s ·Holy Tent [Tabernacle] unclean.

21.verse: This is a lasting ·rule [statute; ordinance; requirement]. Those who sprinkle the cleansing water must also wash their clothes, and anyone who touches the water will be unclean until evening.

22.verse: Anything an unclean person touches becomes unclean, and whoever touches it will be unclean until evening.”

1.verse: Moses Disobeys God - In the first month all the ·people [sons; children] of Israel, the community [congregation; assembly] arrived at the ·Desert [Wilderness] of Zin, and they stayed at Kadesh. There Miriam [Moses’ sister; Ex. 15:20–21; Num. 12:1–13] died and was buried.

2.verse: There was no water for the ·people [community; congregation; assembly], so they ·came together [assembled] against Moses and Aaron.

3.verse: They ·argued with [contended with; brought a case against] Moses and said, “We should have died in front of the LORD as our brothers did.

4.verse: Why did you bring the LORD’s ·people [community; congregation; assembly] into this ·desert [wilderness]? Are we and our animals to die here?

5.verse: Why did you bring us from Egypt to this terrible place? It has no grain, figs, grapevines, or pomegranates, and there’s no water to drink!”

6.verse: So Moses and Aaron left the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] and went to the entrance of the Meeting Tent. There they ·bowed facedown [fell on their faces], and the glory of the LORD [his manifest presence] appeared to them.

7.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

8.verse: “Take your ·walking stick [staff], and you and your brother Aaron should gather the ·people [community; congregation; assembly]. Speak to that rock in front of them so that its water will flow from it. When you bring the water out from that rock, give it to the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] and their animals.”

9.verse: So Moses took the ·stick [staff] from in front of the LORD, as he had said.

10.verse: Moses and Aaron ·gathered [assembled] the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] in front of the rock, and Moses said, “Now listen to me, you ·who turn against God [rebels]! Do you want us [rather than God] to bring water out of this rock?”

11.verse: Then Moses lifted his hand and hit the rock twice with his ·stick [staff; he was supposed to speak to it, 20:8]. Water began pouring out, and the ·people [community; congregation; assembly] and their animals drank it.

12.verse: But the LORD said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not ·believe [trust] me, and because you did not ·honor me as holy [show my holiness] before the ·people [sons/children of Israel], you will not lead ·them [this community; congregation; assembly] into the land I will give them [20:22–29; Deut. 34:1–12].”

13.verse: These are the waters of Meribah [“Argument”], where the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] ·argued with [contended with; brought a case against] the LORD and where he showed them he was holy.

14.verse: Edom Will Not Let Israel Pass - From Kadesh, Moses sent messengers to the king of Edom. He said, “Your brothers, the Israelites, say to you: You know about all the ·troubles [hardship] we have had,

15.verse: how our ·ancestors [fathers] went down into Egypt and we lived there for many years. The people of Egypt ·were cruel to [oppressed] us and our ·ancestors [fathers],

16.verse: but when we cried out to the LORD, he heard ·us [our voice] and sent us an ·angel [messenger] to bring us out of Egypt. “Now we are here at Kadesh, a town on the edge of your ·land [boundaries].

17.verse: Please let us pass through your country. We will not ·touch [pass through] any fields of grain or vineyards, and will not drink water from the wells. We will travel only along the ·king’s road [King’s Highway; a north-south international highway], not turning right or left until we have passed through your ·country [boundaries].”

18.verse: But the king of Edom answered: “You may not pass through here. If you try, I will come and meet you with swords.”

19.verse: The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] answered: “We will go along the ·main road [highway], and if we or our animals drink any of your water, we will pay for it. We only want to walk through. That’s all.”

20.verse: But he answered: “You may not pass through here.” Then the Edomites went out to meet the Israelites with a large and powerful army.

21.verse: The Edomites refused to let them pass through their ·country [boundaries], so the Israelites turned back.

22.verse: Aaron Dies - ·All the Israelites [The sons/children of Israel, all the community/assembly/congregation] moved from Kadesh to Mount Hor,

23.verse: near the border of Edom. There the LORD said to Moses and Aaron,

24.verse: “Aaron will ·die [be gathered to his people]. He will not enter the land that I’m giving to the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel], because you both ·acted [rebelled] against my command at the waters of Meribah [20:1–13].

25.verse: Take Aaron and his son Eleazar up on Mount Hor,

26.verse: and take off Aaron’s special clothes and put them on his son Eleazar. Aaron will die there; he will ·join his people [be gathered].”

27.verse: Moses obeyed the LORD’s command. They climbed up Mount Hor, and all the ·people [community; assembly; congregation] saw them go.

28.verse: Moses took off Aaron’s clothes and put them on Aaron’s son Eleazar. Then Aaron died there on top of the mountain. Moses and Eleazar came back down the mountain,

29.verse: and when all the ·people [community; assembly; congregation] learned that Aaron was dead, ·everyone in [all the house of] Israel cried for him for thirty days.

1.verse: War with the Canaanites - The Canaanite king of Arad lived in the ·southern area [Negev]. When he heard that the Israelites were coming on the road to Atharim, he attacked them and captured some of them.

2.verse: Then the Israelites made ·this promise [a vow] to the LORD: “If you will ·help us defeat these people [give this people into our hands], we will ·completely destroy [devote to the LORD] their cities.”

3.verse: The LORD listened to the Israelites, and he let them defeat the Canaanites. The Israelites ·completely destroyed [devoted to the LORD] the Canaanites and their cities, so the place was named Hormah [“Completely Destroyed”; “Devoted to the Lord”].

4.verse: The Bronze Snake - The Israelites left Mount Hor and went on the road toward the ·Red [or Reed] Sea, in order to go around the country of Edom. But the people became impatient on the way

5.verse: and ·grumbled at [spoke against] God and Moses. They said, “Why did you bring us out of Egypt to die in this ·desert [wilderness]? There is no bread and no water, and we hate this terrible food!”

6.verse: So the LORD sent them ·poisonous [burning] snakes; they bit the people, and many of the ·Israelites [people from Israel] died.

7.verse: The people came to Moses and said, “We sinned when we ·grumbled at [spoke against] you and the LORD. Pray that the LORD will take away these snakes.” So Moses prayed for the people.

8.verse: The LORD said to Moses, “Make a bronze snake, and put it on a pole. When anyone who is bitten looks at it, that person will live.”

9.verse: So Moses made a bronze snake and put it on a pole. Then when a snake bit anyone, that person looked at the bronze snake and lived [2 Kin. 18:4; John 3:14].

10.verse: The Journey to Moab - The ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] went and camped at Oboth.

11.verse: They went from Oboth to Iye Abarim, in the ·desert [wilderness] east of Moab.

12.verse: From there they went and camped in the Zered ·Valley [Wadi].

13.verse: From there they went and camped across the Arnon, in the ·desert [wilderness] just inside the Amorite country. The Arnon is the border between the Moabites and the Amorites.

14.verse: That is why the Book of the Wars of the LORD [a source now lost] says: “ … and Waheb in Suphah, and the ·ravines [wadis], the Arnon,

15.verse: and the slopes of the ·ravines [wadis] that lead to the settlement of Ar. These places are at the border of Moab.”

16.verse: The Israelites went from there to Beer; a well is there where the LORD said to Moses, “Gather the people and I will give them water.”

17.verse: Then the Israelites sang this song: “·Pour out water [Spring up], well! Sing ·about [or to] it.

18.verse: Princes dug this well. ·Important men [Leaders of the people] made it. With their scepters and poles, they dug it.” The people went from the ·desert [wilderness] to Mattanah.

19.verse: From Mattanah they went to Nahaliel and on to Bamoth.

20.verse: From Bamoth they went to the valley of Moab where the top of Mount Pisgah looks over the ·desert [wilderness].

21.verse: Israel Kills Sihon and Og - The Israelites sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, saying,

22.verse: “Let ·us [me] pass through your country. We will not go through any fields of grain or vineyards, or drink water from the wells. We will travel only along the ·king’s road [King’s Highway; 20:17] until we have passed through your ·country [boundaries].”

23.verse: But King Sihon would not let the Israelites pass through his ·country [boundaries]. He gathered his whole army together, and they marched out to meet Israel in the ·desert [wilderness]. At Jahaz they fought the Israelites.

24.verse: Israel ·killed [struck with the sword] the king and captured his land from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River. They took the land as far as the ·Ammonite border [border of the sons of Ammon], which was strongly defended.

25.verse: Israel captured all the Amorite cities and lived in them, taking Heshbon and all the towns around it.

26.verse: Heshbon was the city where Sihon, the Amorite king, lived. In the past he had fought with the king of Moab and had taken all the land from his hand as far as the Arnon.

27.verse: That is why the poets say: “Come to Heshbon and rebuild it; ·rebuild [establish] Sihon’s city.

28.verse: A fire ·began in [went out from] Heshbon; flames came from Sihon’s city. It destroyed Ar in Moab, and it ·burned [or swallowed] the Arnon highlands.

29.verse: ·How terrible for [Woe to] you, Moab! The people of Chemosh are ruined. His sons ran away and his daughters were captured by Sihon, king of the Amorites.

30.verse: But we defeated those Amorites. We ruined their towns from Heshbon to Dibon, and we destroyed them as far as Nophah, near Medeba.”

31.verse: So Israel lived in the land of the Amorites.

32.verse: After Moses sent spies to the town of Jazer, they captured ·the towns around it [its villages], forcing out the Amorites who lived there.

33.verse: Then the Israelites went up the road toward Bashan. Og king of Bashan and his whole army marched out to meet the Israelites, and they fought at Edrei.

34.verse: The LORD said to Moses, “Don’t be afraid of him. I will hand him, his whole army, and his land over to you. Do to him what you did to Sihon, the Amorite king who lived in Heshbon.”

35.verse: So the Israelites ·killed [struck] Og and his sons and all his army; no one was left alive. And they took his land [Deut. 1:4; 3:1–7; Ps. 135:11; 136:20].

1.verse: Balak Sends for Balaam - Then the ·people [sons/children of] of Israel went to the plains of Moab, and they camped near the Jordan River across from Jericho.

2.verse: Balak son of Zippor saw everything the Israelites had done to the Amorites.

3.verse: And Moab ·was scared of [dreaded] so many Israelites; truly, Moab was terrified by them.

4.verse: The Moabites said to the elders of Midian, “·These people [This community/assembly/congregation] will ·take [lick up] everything around us like an ox ·eating [licking] grass.” Balak son of Zippor was the king of Moab at this time.

5.verse: He sent messengers to Balaam son of Beor at Pethor, near the Euphrates River in ·his native land [or the land of Amaw]. Balak said, “A nation has come out of Egypt that covers the land. They have ·camped [settled] next to me,

6.verse: and they are too powerful for me. So come and put a curse on them. Maybe then I can defeat them and ·make them leave [drive them from] the area. I know that if you bless someone, the blessings happen, and if you put a curse on someone, it happens.”

7.verse: The elders of Moab and Midian went with ·payment [fee for divination] in their hands. When they found Balaam, they told him what Balak had said.

8.verse: Balaam said to them, “Stay here for the night, and I will tell you what the LORD tells me.” So the Moabite leaders stayed with him.

9.verse: God came to Balaam and asked, “Who are these men with you?”

10.verse: Balaam said to God, “The king of Moab, Balak son of Zippor, sent them to me with this message:

11.verse: ‘A ·nation [people] has come out of Egypt that ·covers [spreads over] the land. So come and put a curse on them, and maybe I can fight them and force them out of my land.’”

12.verse: But God said to Balaam, “Do not go with them. Don’t put a curse on those people, because I have blessed them.”

13.verse: The next morning Balaam ·awoke [rose] and said to Balak’s leaders, “Go back to your own country; the LORD has refused to let me go with you.”

14.verse: So the Moabite leaders went back to Balak and said, “Balaam refused to come with us.”

15.verse: So Balak sent other leaders—this time there were more of them, and they were more ·important [distinguished].

16.verse: They went to Balaam and said, “Balak son of Zippor says this: Please don’t let anything stop you from coming to me.

17.verse: I will ·pay you very well [make you wealthy; honor you], and I will do what you say. Come and put a curse on these people for me.”

18.verse: But Balaam answered Balak’s servants, “King Balak could give me his palace full of silver and gold, but I cannot ·disobey [transgress] the LORD my God in anything, great or small.

19.verse: You stay here tonight as the other men did, and I will find out what more the LORD tells me.”

20.verse: That night God came to Balaam and said, “These men have come to ask you to go with them. Go, but only do what I tell you.”

21.verse: Balaam’s Donkey Speaks - Balaam got up the next morning and put a saddle on his donkey. Then he went with the Moabite leaders.

22.verse: But God became angry because Balaam went, so the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD stood in the road to ·stop [challenge] Balaam. Balaam was riding his donkey, and he had two servants with him.

23.verse: When the donkey saw the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD standing in the road with a drawn sword in his hand, the donkey left the road and went into the field. Balaam ·hit [struck] the donkey to force her back on the road.

24.verse: Later, the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD stood on a narrow path between two vineyards, with walls on both sides.

25.verse: Again the donkey saw the angel of the LORD, and she walked close to one wall, ·crushing [squeezing; scraping] Balaam’s foot against it. So he ·hit [struck] her again.

26.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD went ahead again and stood at a narrow place, too narrow to turn left or right.

27.verse: When the donkey saw the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD, she lay down under Balaam. This made him so angry that he ·hit [struck] her with his stick.

28.verse: Then the LORD made the donkey talk, and she said to Balaam, “What have I done to make you ·hit [strike] me three times?”

29.verse: Balaam answered the donkey, “You have made me look foolish! I wish I had a sword in my hand! I would kill you right now!”

30.verse: But the donkey said to Balaam, “·I am [Am I not…?] your very own donkey, which you have ridden for years. Have I ever done this to you before?” “No,” Balaam said.

31.verse: Then the LORD opened the eyes of Balaam and let Balaam see the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD, who was standing in the road with his sword drawn in his hand. Then Balaam bowed facedown on the ground.

32.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD asked Balaam, “Why have you ·hit [struck] your donkey three times? I have stood here to ·stop [challenge] you, because what you are doing is wrong.

33.verse: The donkey saw me and turned away from me three times [it was more spiritually sensitive than Balaam]. If she had not turned away, I would have killed you by now, but I would have let her live.”

34.verse: Then Balaam said to the ·angel [messenger] of the LORD, “I have sinned; I did not know you were standing in the road to stop me. If I am wrong, I will go back.”

35.verse: The ·angel [messenger] of the LORD said to Balaam, “Go with these men, but say only what I tell you.” So Balaam went with Balak’s leaders.

36.verse: When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went out to meet him at Ar in Moab, which was beside the Arnon, at the edge of his ·country [boundary].

37.verse: Balak said to Balaam, “·I had asked you before [Did I not send for you…?] to come quickly. Why didn’t you come to me? ·I am [Am I not…?] able to ·reward you well [give you wealth].”

38.verse: But Balaam answered, “I have come to you now, but I can’t say just anything. I can only say what God tells me to say.”

39.verse: Then Balaam went with Balak to Kiriath Huzoth.

40.verse: Balak offered cattle and sheep as a sacrifice and gave some meat to Balaam and the leaders with him.

41.verse: The next morning Balak took Balaam to Bamoth Baal; from there he could see the edge of the ·Israelite camp [people].

1.verse: Balaam’s First Message - Balaam said to Balak, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven ·male sheep [rams] for me.”

2.verse: Balak did what Balaam asked, and they offered a bull and a ·male sheep [ram] on each of the altars.

3.verse: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here beside your burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] and I will go. If the LORD comes to me, I will tell you whatever he shows me.” Then Balaam went to a ·higher place [or barren height].

4.verse: God came to Balaam there, and Balaam said to him, “I have prepared seven altars, and I have offered a bull and a ·male sheep [ram] on each altar.”

5.verse: The LORD ·told Balaam what he should say [put a word in the mouth of Balaam]. Then the LORD said, “Go back to Balak and ·give him this message [thus you will speak].”

6.verse: So Balaam went back to Balak. Balak and all the leaders of Moab were still standing beside his burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17]

7.verse: when Balaam gave them this ·message [or oracle; or poem]: “Balak brought me here from Aram; the king of Moab brought me from the eastern mountains. Balak said, ‘Come, put a curse on the people of Jacob for me. Come, call down evil on the people of Israel.’

8.verse: But ·God has not cursed them, so I cannot curse them [how can I curse what God has not cursed?]. ·The LORD has not called down evil on them, so I cannot call down evil on them [How can I call down evil on/denounce what the LORD has not called down evil/denouced?].

9.verse: I see them from the top of the ·mountains [cliffs]; I see them from the hills. I see a people who live alone, who think they are different from other nations [Ex. 19:5–6].

10.verse: No one can number the ·many people [dust; Gen. 13:16; 28:14] of Jacob, and no one can count a ·fourth [or dust cloud] of Israel. Let me die like ·good [virtuous; upright] people, and let me end up like them!”

11.verse: Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you here to curse my enemies, but you have only blessed them!”

12.verse: But Balaam answered, “·I must [Must I not…?] say what the LORD ·tells me to say [put in my mouth].”

13.verse: Balaam’s Second Message - Then Balak said to him, “Come with me to another place, where you can also see the people. But you can only see part of them, not all of them [perhaps he could curse a part of Israel]. Curse them for me from there.”

14.verse: So Balak took Balaam to the field of Zophim, on top of Mount Pisgah. There Balak built seven altars and offered a bull and a ·male sheep [ram] on each altar.

15.verse: So Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here by your burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17], and I will meet with God over there.”

16.verse: So the LORD came to Balaam and ·told him what to say [put a word in his mouth]. Then he said, “Go back to Balak and say ·such and such [thus].”

17.verse: So Balaam went to Balak, where he and the leaders of Moab were standing beside his burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17]. Balak asked him, “What did the LORD say?”

18.verse: Then Balaam gave this ·message [or oracle; or poem]: “Stand up, Balak, and listen. Hear me, son of Zippor.

19.verse: God is not a human being, and he will not lie. He is not a human, and he does not change his mind. What he says he will do, ·he does [will he not do it?]. What he promises, ·he makes come true [will he not fulfill it/make it come true?].

20.verse: He ·told [commanded] me to bless them, so I cannot change the blessing.

21.verse: He ·has found [observes] no wrong in the people of Jacob; he saw no ·fault [trouble] in Israel. The LORD their God is with them, and they praise their King.

22.verse: God brought them out of Egypt; they are ·as strong as [like the horns of] a wild ox.

23.verse: No ·tricks [divination] will work on the people of Jacob, and no magic will work against Israel. People now say about ·them [Jacob], ‘Look what God has done for Israel!’

24.verse: The people rise up like a lioness; they get up like a lion. Lions don’t rest until they have eaten prey, until they have drunk ·their enemies’ blood [the blood of corpses].”

25.verse: Then Balak said to Balaam, “You haven’t cursed these people, so at least don’t bless them!”

26.verse: Balaam answered Balak, “·I told [Did I not tell…?] you before that I can only do what the LORD tells me.”

27.verse: Balaam’s Third Message - Then Balak said to Balaam, “Come, I will take you to another place. Maybe ·God will be pleased [it will be right in the eyes/sight of God] to let you curse them from there.”

28.verse: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, the mountain that looks over the ·desert [wasteland; or Jeshimon].

29.verse: Balaam told Balak, “Build me seven altars here and prepare for me seven bulls and seven ·male sheep [rams].”

30.verse: Balak did what Balaam asked, and he offered a bull and a ·male sheep [ram] on each altar.

1.verse: Balaam saw that ·the LORD wanted [it was good in the eyes/sight of the LORD] to bless Israel, so he did not try to use any ·magic [divination] but looked toward the ·desert [wilderness].

2.verse: When Balaam ·saw [lifted his eyes and saw] the Israelites camped in their tribes, the Spirit of God ·took control of [was on] him,

3.verse: and he gave this ·message [or oracle; or poem]: “This is the ·message [utterance] of Balaam son of Beor, the ·message [utterance] of a man ·who sees clearly [whose eye is open];

4.verse: this is the ·message [utterance] of a man who hears the words of God. I see a vision from the Almighty, and my eyes are open as I fall before him.

5.verse: ·Your tents are beautiful [How beautiful/fair are your tents], people of Jacob! ·So are your homes [Your dwellings], Israel!

6.verse: Your tents spread out like ·valleys [wadis], like gardens beside a river. They are like ·spices [aloes] planted by the LORD, like cedar trees growing by the water.

7.verse: Israel’s water buckets will always ·be full [or flow], and their ·crops [seed] will have plenty of water. Their king will be greater than Agag [perhaps a dynastic name of the Amalekites (Ex. 17:8–13); 1 Sam. 15:7–9, 32–33]; their kingdom will be very great.

8.verse: God brought them out of Egypt; they are ·as strong as [like the horns of] a wild ox. They will defeat their enemies and break their enemies’ bones; they will ·shoot [strike] them with arrows.

9.verse: Like a lion, they lie waiting to attack; like a lioness, ·no one would be brave enough to wake [who will rouse…?] them. Anyone who blesses you will be blessed, and anyone who curses you will be cursed [Gen. 12:3].”

10.verse: Then Balak was angry with Balaam, and he ·pounded his fist [or struck his hands together]. He said to Balaam, “I called you here to curse my enemies, but you have continued to bless them three times.

11.verse: Now go home! I said I would ·pay you well [make you wealthy], but the LORD has ·made you lose [denied you] your reward.”

12.verse: Balaam said to Balak, “When you sent messengers to me, ·I told [did I not tell…?] them,

13.verse: ‘Balak could give me his ·palace [house] filled with silver and gold, but I still cannot ·go against [transgress] the LORD’s commands. I could not do anything, good or bad, on my own, but I must say what the LORD says.’

14.verse: Now I am going back to my own people, but I will ·tell [advise] you what these people will do to your people in the ·future [later days].”

15.verse: Balaam’s Final Message - Then Balaam gave this ·message [or oracle; or poem]: “This is the ·message [utterance] of Balaam son of Beor, the ·message [utterance] of a man ·who sees clearly [whose eye is open];

16.verse: this is the ·message [utterance] of a man who hears the words of God. I know well the Most High God. I see a vision from the Almighty, and my eyes are open as I fall before him.

17.verse: I see someone ·who will come someday [but not now], ·someone who will come, but not soon [I see him, but not near]. A star will come from Jacob; a ·ruler [scepter] will rise from Israel [Saul, then David and his descendants, including the Messiah]. He will crush the heads of the Moabites and smash the skulls of the sons of Sheth [identity uncertain].

18.verse: Edom will be conquered; his enemy Edom will be conquered, but Israel will grow ·wealthy [or valiant].

19.verse: A ruler will come from the descendants of Jacob and will destroy those left in the city.”

20.verse: Then Balaam saw Amalek and gave this message: “Amalek was the most important nation, but Amalek will be destroyed at last [the book of Esther tells the story of the final destruction of Amalek; Haman is a descendant of Agag; 24:7].”

21.verse: Then Balaam saw the Kenites and gave this ·message [or oracle; or poem]: “Your home is ·safe [enduring], like a nest on a ·cliff [rock].

22.verse: But you Kenites will be burned up; ·Assyria will [How long will Assyria…?] keep you captive.”

23.verse: Then Balaam gave this ·message [or oracle; or poem]: “·No one [Who…?] can live when God does this.

24.verse: Ships will sail from the shores of ·Cyprus [Kittim] and ·defeat [afflict] Assyria and Eber, but they will also be destroyed.”

25.verse: Then Balaam got up and returned home, and Balak also went on his way.

1.verse: Israel Worships Baal at Peor - While the people of Israel were still camped at ·Acacia [Shittim], the men began ·sinning sexually [to prostitute themselves] with Moabite women [on the advice of Balaam who found another way to get his money; 31:16].

2.verse: The women invited them to their sacrifices to their gods, and the ·Israelites [people] ate food there and worshiped these gods.

3.verse: So the Israelites ·began to worship [yoked themselves to] Baal of Peor, and the LORD was very angry with them.

4.verse: The LORD said to Moses, “Get all the leaders of the people and ·kill [impale] them in open daylight in the presence of the LORD. Then the LORD will not be angry with the people of Israel.”

5.verse: So Moses said to Israel’s judges, “Each of you must ·put to death [kill] your people who have become ·worshipers of [yoked to] Baal of Peor.”

6.verse: Moses and the Israelites were gathered at the entrance to the Meeting Tent, crying there. Then an ·Israelite man [man of the sons/children of Israel] brought a Midianite woman to his ·brothers [family] in plain sight of Moses and all the ·people [community; congregation; assembly].

7.verse: Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, the priest, saw this, so he ·left the meeting [rose up from the community/congregation/assembly] and ·got [took in his hand] his spear.

8.verse: He followed the Israelite into his ·tent [vaulted/newlywed tent] and drove his spear through the belly of both the Israelite man and the Midianite woman [while they were embracing]. Then the ·terrible sickness [plague] among the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] stopped.

9.verse: This ·sickness [plague] had killed twenty-four thousand people.

10.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

11.verse: “Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, the priest, has saved the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] from my anger. He hates sin as much as I do. ·Since he tried to save my honor among them [Because of his zeal in their midst], I will not kill them in my zeal.

12.verse: So tell Phinehas that I am making my ·peace agreement [covenant/treaty of peace] with him.

13.verse: He and his ·descendants [seed] will ·always be priests [have a covenant/treaty of eternal/perpetual priesthood], because he had ·great concern for the honor of [passion/zeal for] his God. He ·removed the sins of the Israelites so they would belong to God [provided atonement for the sons/children of Israel].”

14.verse: The Israelite man who was ·killed [struck] with the Midianite woman was named Zimri son of Salu. He was the leader of a ·family [ancestral clan] in the tribe of Simeon.

15.verse: And the name of the Midianite woman who was ·put to death [struck] was Cozbi daughter of Zur, who was the chief of a Midianite ·family [ancestral clan].

16.verse: The LORD said to Moses,

17.verse: “·The Midianites are your enemies [Harrass the Midianites], and you should ·kill [strike] them.

18.verse: They have already ·made you their enemies [harrassed you], because they tricked you at Peor and because of their sister Cozbi, the daughter of a Midianite leader. She was the woman who was killed when the ·sickness [plague] came because the people sinned at Peor.”

1.verse: The People Are Counted - After the ·great sickness [plague], the LORD said to Moses and Eleazar son of Aaron, the priest,

2.verse: “·Count [Take a census of; Lift the head of] all the ·people of Israel [community/congregation of the sons/children of Israel] by ·families [clans], all the men who are twenty years old or older who will serve in the army of Israel [like a military registration; chapter 1 counts the generation that came out of Egypt; this counts the one that would enter the land].”

3.verse: Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke to the people on the plains of Moab near the Jordan River, across from Jericho. They said,

4.verse: “Count the men [supplied from v. 2] twenty years old or older, as the LORD commanded Moses.” Here are the ·Israelites [sons/children of Israel] who came out of Egypt:

5.verse: The ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Reuben, the first son born to Israel, was counted. From Hanoch came the Hanochite ·family group [clan]; from Pallu came the Palluite ·family group [clan];

6.verse: from Hezron came the Hezronite ·family group [clan]; from Carmi came the Carmite ·family group [clan].

7.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] of Reuben, and the total number of men was 43,730.

8.verse: The son of Pallu was Eliab,

9.verse: and Eliab’s sons were Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram were the ·leaders [conveners of the community/congregation/assembly] who turned against Moses and Aaron and ·followed [were in the assembly of] Korah when he ·turned [rebelled] against the LORD.

10.verse: The earth opened up and swallowed them and Korah; they died at the same time the fire burned up the 250 men [16:1–40]. This was a warning,

11.verse: but the children of Korah did not die.

12.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] in the ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Simeon: From Nemuel came the Nemuelite ·family group [clan]; from Jamin came the Jaminite ·family group [clan]; from Jakin came the Jakinite ·family group [clan];

13.verse: from Zerah came the Zerahite ·family group [clan]; from Shaul came the Shaulite ·family group [clan].

14.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] of Simeon, and the total number of men was 22,200.

15.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] in the ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Gad: From Zephon came the Zephonite ·family group [clan]; from Haggi came the Haggite ·family group [clan]; from Shuni came the Shunite ·family group [clan];

16.verse: from Ozni came the Oznite ·family group [clan]; from Eri came the Erite ·family group [clan];

17.verse: from Arodi came the Arodite ·family group [clan]; from Areli came the Arelite ·family group [clan].

18.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] of Gad, and the total number of men was 40,500.

19.verse: Two of Judah’s sons, Er and Onan, died in Canaan [Gen. 38:6–11].

20.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] in the ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Judah: From Shelah came the Shelanite ·family group [clan]; from Perez came the Perezite ·family group [clan]; from Zerah came the Zerahite ·family group [clan].

21.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] from Perez: From Hezron came the Hezronite ·family group [clan]; from Hamul came the Hamulite ·family group [clan].

22.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] of Judah, and the total number of men was 76,500.

23.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] in the ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Issachar: From Tola came the Tolaite ·family group [clan]; from Puah came the Puite ·family group [clan];

24.verse: from Jashub came the Jashubite ·family group [clan]; from Shimron came the Shimronite ·family group [clan].

25.verse: These were the ·family groups [clan] of Issachar, and the total number of men was 64,300.

26.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] in the ·tribe [sons; descendants] of Zebulun: From Sered came the Seredite ·family group [clan]; from Elon came the Elonite ·family group [clan]; from Jahleel came the Jahleelite ·family group [clan].

27.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] of Zebulun, and the total number of men was 60,500.

29.verse: These were the ·family groups [clans] of [the sons/descendants of] Manasseh: From Makir came the Makirite ·family group [clan] (Makir was the father of Gilead); from Gilead came the Gileadite ·family group [clan].
